Problem:
Consider the analytical solution of the heat equation \\( u_t = ku_{xx} \\) under initial conditions that can be represented as a Fourier transform. An operation \\( f(u) = u + e^{i\\omega_0 x} \\) is introduced, where \\( \\omega_0 \\) is a constant frequency.

If \\( f(u) \\) is applied to an initial temperature distribution \\( u_0 \\) and then the system is allowed to evolve according to the heat equation without further intervention, will the temperature distribution \\( u(x,t) \\) at a later time t match that obtained from evolving \\( u_0 \\) alone?
Explanation: Applying \\( f(u) \\) modifies the initial conditions of the system by adding a sinusoidal component. Given the linearity of the heat equation, this additional term evolves independently under the heat equation, resulting in a different temperature distribution at any later time due to the influence of the term \\( e^{i\\omega_0 x} \\) propagating and diffusing over time.
